Review: Mary Queen of Scots

19/01/2019

Francesca Iucci reviews the new heart-breaking historical drama

Image by

By James Bithell

9/10

Director: Josie Rourke

Starring: Saoirse Ronan, Margot Robbie

Length: 125 minutes

Rating: 15

 

Saoirse Ronan shines once again in her latest production, Mary Queen of Scots, the historical drama narrating the events and decisions that led to Mary Stuartâ€™s tragic end, as well as focusing on the intense and delicate relationship between Mary Stuart (Saoirse Ronan) and Elizabeth I (Margot Robbie). The direction of Josie Rourke seems to concentrate on dualities as breath-taking landscapes are contrasted by interior settings that often convey a sense of confinement. The film completely succeeds in its intent as the viewer is offered with the realities of both monarchs but also understands from the beginning that the prevalent attention should be on Mary Stuart. Worthy of attention is also the representation of these two powerful women on the screen; the narration isnâ€™t biased, and the audience manages to sympathise with both characters to the same extent.

Watching the film, the theme of control circulates around both Mary and Elizabeth; they are female monarchs
living in a period of time where women had little, if no choice at all. It is very interesting to observe how the other characters, mostly men, react to these womenâ€™s independence. Especially in Maryâ€™s case, it is quite easy to notice that most of the decisions that lead to her downfall are actually executed by men and that whenever she presents herself as a passionate individual, she isnâ€™t taken seriously by her council or by her half-brother James Stewart (James McArdle). For example, she is considered accountable for the death of her second husband Lord Darnley (Jack Lowden), but the people responsible for this act are actually the men of her court, the 4th Earl of Lennox (Brendan Coyle) gives the order and the Earl of Bothwell (Martin Compston) carries it out without any knowledge on Maryâ€™s behalf. Mary is a queen who is not actually allowed to choose, and this is proved not only by the story itself, but by the way she is frequently addressed as â€˜Madameâ€™, instead of â€˜Your
Majestyâ€™.

 Saoirse Ronanâ€™s performance has to be mentioned in her ability to fully transform into Mary Stuart, particularly taking into consideration the difficulties Mary experienced in her life. Especially in the depiction of the violent events that Mary went through, Ronan breaks our hearts over and over again. In Mary Queen of Scots, Ronan shows us that she is able to thrive as an actress in any situation, such as giving birth, speaking French, and the more complex portrayal of sexual assault and rape. The amount of violence and disrespect in Mary Stuartâ€™s life strongly strikes a chord with the audience.



In Elizabethâ€™s case, her council shows more tolerant behaviour in listening to her, partly because she presents herself as Maryâ€™s opposite. While Mary is passionate, and convinced in her ideas, the throne has forced Elizabeth to embrace the â€˜manâ€™ inside her. Despite her personal desire to bear children, she has picked the country over her own happiness. Margot Robbie truly leaves her mark as Elizabeth I, and turns an apparently â€˜coldâ€™ character into a striking and powerful image for the audience to empathise with. The councilâ€™s approach to Elizabeth is not as brutal as the one Mary receives, and part of this is caused by the differences in their reigns; Mary is treated without any respect by her council, and she is therefore less likely to agree with its plans, but on the other side Elizabeth has an open approach to her councilâ€™s proposals.

An element that contributes to the audienceâ€™s perception of Elizabeth I is the use of make-up. In fact, only at the beginning of the film do we get to see a young and healthy Elizabeth with her strawberry-blonde locks. The extraordinary work of Jenny Shircore, hair and make-up artist is truly shocking as the film progresses. Slowly, Elizabethâ€™s issues with alopecia, smallpox, and scars come into the picture, and Margot Robbieâ€™s natural beauty is transformed into an appalling overly-white face of make-up. Additionally, the redness of her wigs turns more intense, and the introduction of red lipstick displays Robbieâ€™s version of Elizabeth I as very drastic. Elizabethâ€™s use of make-up also represents the queenâ€™s constant insecurity in comparison to Maryâ€™s beauty.

 As the story progresses, the audience realises more and more the powerful bond between Mary and Elizabeth. In such a time period, these two queens are the only ones who can understand the struggles of the other. In their letters, they often refer to each other as â€˜sistersâ€™, and it is striking to discover Maryâ€™s request to Elizabeth to be her sonâ€™s godmother. The film explores the connection between Mary and Elizabeth in a way that makes us recognise that rivalry is actually pushed upon them by others. The film includes Mary and Elizabethâ€™s meeting scene, an event that historically never took place, but which completely encapsulates the charactersâ€™ relationship; Mary and Elizabeth long for each otherâ€™s friendship and support, but at the same time perceive the difficult circumstances of the time period they live in.

 Mary Stuartâ€™s heart-breaking story and the complicated relationship between Mary and Elizabeth are perfectly displayed by Saoirse Ronan and Margot Robbieâ€™s outstanding performances. Although Mary Queen of Scots tackles with intense and emotional experiences, it is a must-watch especially in an era concerned with female independence.
